sentence: Nomura has upgraded Showa Denko (4004.JP) from neutral to buy and has more than doubled its target price on the stock from JPY1,500 a share to JPY3,450 a share, which implies 14% upside.

Analyst Yifan Zhang has lifted his earnings estimates for Showa Denko on stronger-than-expected demand for graphite electrodes, which are used in the production of high performance lithium-ion batteries, and hard disk media.

We have hiked our earnings forecasts and raised our rating to Buy on a rapid recovery in graphite electrode prices, stronger-than expected demand for hard disk (HD) media for use in data centers, and stronger-than-expected demand for petrochemicals too.

We retain our 18/12 target P/E of around 12x versus the average of around 16x for the Russell/Nomura Large Cap index (ex financials) because our medium-term operating profit CAGR forecast of just over 2% is lower than the benchmark average of 5.6%, but our 18/12 operating profit forecast is much higher than the QUICK consensus forecast of ¥58.6bn.

Zhang expects a sharp rise in graphite electrode prices on tougher environmental regulations in China which has lead to the closure of several small graphite electrode producers, mainly in Henan and Hebei provinces:

We have raised our 18/12 operating profit forecast from ¥35.4bn to ¥70.0bn.
We had expected graphite electrode prices to peg level y-y in 18/12, but we now expect them to rise 50%.

Based on what a major Chinese graphite electrode producer and steel industry representatives told us during our business trip to China last week, the Chinese government has shut down more than a dozen small graphite electrode producers (with annual production capacity of around 300,000t, equivalent to around 30% of total Chinese capacity in 2016), mainly in Henan and Hebei provinces, after investigations carried out in Mar-Jun 2017 revealed inadequate environmental controls.
This has led to a sharp rise in Chinese spot prices for graphite electrodes that is likely to results in substantial rises in selling prices at Showa Denko too in 18/12.
Daiwa has also raised its raised sales volume assumption for HD media.
The broker now expects growth to remain flat in 2018, compared to 5% fall previously, on a greater-than-expected rise in demand for HD media for use in data centers.
Showa Denko shares are up 81% this year and trade at 13 times forward earnings, which is in line with its five-year average.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
